The perfect playlist for the holiday season can get everyone in the Christmas spirit. Christmas music is one of the many highlights of the holiday season. Having the perfect playlist for this time of year is essential. Here are a few song ideas to add on a playlist this holiday season to set the tone for the most wonderful time of the year. Certain songs have a way of connecting us with our memories and can serve as a reminder about them through the Christmas season. ‚ÄúMy favorite Christmas song is Jingle Bells,‚Äù junior Bri Barnett said. ‚ÄúAround Christmas time my grandpa and I would do something special and sing this song. He ended up passing away last year but it was always my favorite thing to do.‚Äù Songs that capture the Christmas spirit and bring out the holiday fun are perfect to have for a playlist. ‚ÄúI like Christmas Tree Farm by Taylor Swift,‚Äù sophomore Violet Hayter said. ‚ÄúI add this song to my playlist every year because it really captures the Christmas spirit and makes me happy.‚Äù The transition from Christmas time and celebrating the season, to the end of the year can be a sweeter with songs to capture it. ‚ÄúHappy Xmas (War is Over) by John Lennon,‚Äù junior Lena King said. ‚ÄúBecause I feel like it truly encapsulates the feeling of the year finally being over and the choir is really beautiful.‚Äù Christmas songs make the listeners feel excited in their own ways and ready for the holiday season. ‚ÄúJingle bells is the best song for Christmas,‚Äù junior Charley Landers said. ‚ÄúBecause it makes me feel like I‚Äôm in ‚ÄòPolar Express‚Äô or something. Its giving calmness.‚Äù The art of Christmas songs truly bring great memories to the listeners, letting them associate Christmas with a particular song. ‚Äú‚ÄôHave Yourself a Merry Little Christmas‚Äô by Frank Sinatra is my pick,‚Äù sophomore Mayra Ayarely said. ‚ÄúMy best friend‚Äôs mom always puts this song on when we‚Äôre doing any sort of Christmas activity so now I associate this song with those memories. Also, I just love Frank Sinatra.‚Äù View Story Comments 0 Like This Story Share on FacebookShare on XEmail this StoryPrint this Story Leave a Comment Donate to The Voice of the Wildkats $410 $1000 Contributed Our Goal Your donation will support the student journalists of Willis High School. Your contribution will allow us to purchase equipment and cover our annual website hosting costs. researchResults.content: that high school feeling - playlists music writing | Ask MetaFilter New Site Beta Testing || ChatGPT policy updated || February Site Update || Non Profit FAQ Ask MetaFilter ============== querying the hive mind Log In Sign Up MetaFilter AskMeFi FanFare Projects Music Jobs IRL MetaTalk More Best Of Podcast Chat Labs Mall Search MetaFilter‚Ä¶ Menu Home FAQ About Archives Tags Popular Random that high school feeling October 20, 2010 10:48 AM Subscribe ================================================================================================================================ Songs that evoke high school nostalgia? It's that time again! I'm close to starting my fourth novel, and that means composing a playlist with metafilter's help. This book is a dark contemporary young adult book, set in the sort of central/southern California setting where I grew up. Not in summer, but in fall or winter, with overcast skies and oaks and eucalyptus trees and strawberry fields and shivering at beach bonfires and grimy coffee shops. I listen to the same long playlist every time I sit down to write a book. For this book, I'm looking for songs that convey a sense of high school nostalgia. Songs that re-evoke that excitement, fear, wistfulness, longing, confusion from your teenage years. Maybe they're songs from a pivotal time in your life. Maybe they were just hugely popular back then. Ideally, music you love; "Hit Me Baby One More Time" takes me back but it's not exactly conducive to writing. (Or listening.) I prefer rock of any kind, from indie to folk to punk to grunge -- I'm sure the subgenre depends on when you were in high school. But I'm also looking for newer songs that evoke that thrill/terror of being a teenager. The lyrics don't necessarily have to fit, but of course it's extra cool if they do. For me, some of them are "1979" by The Smashing Pumpkins (and the video!), "Glycerine" by Bush, "High and Dry" by Radiohead, etc.; songs not from my high school years, but that still evoke that feeling are "Don't Change" by INXS, "Re: Stacks" by Bon Iver, "The Last Word" by Chris Flew, "Slow Show" by The National (but that song makes me nostalgic for all times, including now). There's a definite genre theme there, but really I'd love to know your choices whatever the genre. Thanks!!! You have no idea how much this helps me write -- Metafilter's definitely going in the acknowledgments of my next book(s). posted by changeling to Media & Arts (56 answers total) 28 users marked this as a favorite The pixies doolittle got me through high school. posted by TheBones at 10:54 AM on October 20, 2010 As someone who went to hs in SoCal in the 90's, I'd have to say Ska. Lots and lots of Ska. And some surfer punk stuff. Reel big fish, No Doubt, Squirrel Nut Zippers, The Ziggens, Sublime, The Mighty Mighty Bosstones, The Aquabats, etc. posted by Arbac at 10:55 AM on October 20, 2010 Simple Minds - Don't You Forget About Me for the 80's posted by Sukey Says at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 [4 favorites] I think the Violent Femmes' eponymous first album is the sound of being sixteen, but then, I grew up in the late 80s and early 90s. Their songs' being vulgar and somewhat transgressive is what I think contributes that feel...it just fits with the sense of teenagers always wanting to be older than they are. posted by jocelmeow at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Popular by Nada Surf Freshman by The Verve Pipe posted by zoomorphic at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 the freshmen -- the verve pipe spiderwebs -- no doubt banditos -- the refreshments just -- radiohead & anything from the clueless soundtrack posted by crawfo at 10:58 AM on October 20, 2010 Dropout by Urge Overkill posted by kimdog at 11:00 AM on October 20, 2010 And now, with more link! Dropout by Urge Overkill posted by kimdog at 11:01 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] I went to high school in the 90s too. Some of my old favorites that evoke that high school feeling: - The Verve: The Freshmen (on preview, nthing this one) - Red Hot Chili Peppers: Under the Bridge - No Doubt: Don't Speak - Pearl Jam: Black - Candlebox: Far Behind - Violent Femmes: Kiss Off posted by spinto at 11:01 AM on October 20, 2010 The Fun Boy Three version of Our Lips Are Sealed has always had a really school/teenage sort of feeling for me. oh my god look at terry hall's hair Also Blur's Boys And Girls and Pulp's Mis-Shapes from my teenage Britpop years. And more recently, The Long Blondes' Once And Never Again. posted by permafrost at 11:02 AM on October 20, 2010 Also went to high school in Southern California. 2nding Sublime, although it reminds me of summer, not fall. Definitely Weezer, I'd say anything on The Blue Album. 3rd eye blind and Matchbox 20 always remind me of high school (but I don't think I'd want them on a playlist, ever). Neko Case "That Teenage Feeling" gives me a good nostalgic feeling. Also: The Violent Femmes, Elliot Smith, Jeff Buckley, Fiona Apple, 311, Incubus... The Romeo and Juliet Soundtrack. Bands from my older brother's ipod (who still listens to all the same music we listened to in high school): Radiohead, Nada Surf, Everclear, Hey Stroker, MxPx... I'll try to come back with more. And please post your playlist when you're done!!! On preview: Yes to Red Hot Chili Peppers posted by thankyouforyourconsideration at 11:05 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Some songs at the nostalgic and/or wistful end of the spectrum that have that effect on me (was a teenager during the mid-1990s in the UK): David's Last Summer by Pulp; The Summer House by the Divine Comedy; Wake Up Boo by the Boo Radleys; Lost Myself by the Longpigs; Mmm Mmm Mmm Mmm by the Crash Test Dummies; Today by the Smashing Pumpkins. posted by greycap at 11:06 AM on October 20, 2010 Pop A Top by Jim Ed Brown I am OLD posted by raildr at 11:07 AM on October 20, 2010 For me it would be U2's first album, Boy. Lots of songs about growing up, being a teenager, being confused about the world. Classic Edge guitar. Very 80s. Also the song Boy/Girl, off their first EP. I wore out a cassette I made with every B-Side up through the Joshua Tree. Along those lines The Alarm had a lot of songs about believing in yourself and other crap like that. 68 Guns, Knife Edge, Where Were You Hiding (When the storm broke), Strength. More great 80s guitar. posted by bondcliff at 11:09 AM on October 20, 2010 Psychedelic Furs, Love My Way posted by Cool Papa Bell at 11:19 AM on October 20, 2010 Seconding Weezer - Pinkerton and the Green Album in particular posted by aintthattheway at 11:22 AM on October 20, 2010 It came out twenty years before I graduated high school (and that was almost twenty years ago), but there might not be a song more evocative of high school in general than Big Star's "Thirteen". The first time I heard it I was just blown away by how perfect it felt, and despite its vintage it couldn't sound fresher if it were written yesterday and recorded this morning. For me personally--the Cure's "Disintegration" album. "Smells Like Teen Spirit". Metallica's black album, which reminds me of dirty dark desert parties. posted by padraigin at 11:23 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Green Day - Good Riddance (Time of Your Life) Eve 6 - Here's to the Night posted by morganannie at 11:23 AM on October 20, 2010 November Rain by Guns 'N Roses. posted by Sassyfras at 11:24 AM on October 20, 2010 Catch 22 - Kristina She Don't Know I Exist posted by namewithoutwords at 11:40 AM on October 20, 2010 New Radicals - You Get What You Give posted by Mr Mister at 11:41 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Led Zeppelin, pretty much anything by them. I remember watching The Song Remains The Same and that was the soundtrack for my high school years. KISS was big then too. This was prior to 1982. posted by JJ86 at 11:47 AM on October 20, 2010 Guster's "One Man Wrecking Machine" and "Homecoming King" are on the looking-back-on-high-school end of things, but I'd say very appropriate. A lot of Jimmy Eat World songs capture all the high school emotions for me. "The Middle" was big just before I entered high school, and "Your House," "Authority Song," and "Kill" are very good at evoking the self-conscious uncertainty of having a crush on someone and worrying about every single thing you do around them because what if you look like an idiot, and what if they don't like you back, is everyone looking at me, and all that drama. Finally, this may just be because these guys are from the same town as I am, but "Madeline" by Tickle Me Pink vividly conjures up memories from my high school days. posted by lilac girl at 11:48 AM on October 20, 2010 Pearl Jam - Jeremy and Daughter both remind me of high school posted by yawper at 11:49 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Songs that re-evoke that...wistfulness, longing These aren't necessarily songs that you would strongly associate with high school, but they definitely evoke wistfulness and longing for something that has passed. The Moody Blues - Your Wildest Dreams Lou Reed - Perfect Day posted by jedicus at 11:50 AM on October 20, 2010 For me that song is San Dimas High School Football Rules, by The Ataris. posted by just_ducky at 11:51 AM on October 20, 2010 American Music - Violent Femmes Story of My Life - Social Distortion Surf Wax America - Weezer Waiting Room - Fugazi 3 Days - Jane's Addiction Pepper - Butthole Surfers What's Up? - 4 Non Blondes Bad Town - Operation Ivy Punk Rock Girl - Dead Milkmen 1 Crush - Garbage Everybody Knows - Leonard Cohen Jerry Was a Racecar Driver - Primus Here Comes Your Man - Pixies Tuesday Morning - the Pogues posted by iamkimiam at 11:55 AM on October 20, 2010 [3 favorites] Concrete Blonde - Tomorrow Wendy, Joey Ben Folds Five - Brick Sinead O'Connor - Nothing Compares 2 U U2 - With or Without You And not rap, but the lyrics are all about high school: John Mayer - No Such Thing. I am a Mayer fan, but I hate this song. However, for wistful and longing, try Something's Missing. It's much better. posted by yawper at 12:00 PM on October 20, 2010 "Linger" by The Cranberries. posted by Lucinda at 12:00 PM on October 20, 2010 You want Losing My Religion by REM. I would want the first Counting Crows album, maybe some Gin Blossoms. If you were cooler than that in high school (and it sounds it), I think you want the Smiths. posted by clavicle at 12:03 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Anything by Rush or Boston immediately brings me back to an old van filled with hockey players. (On the way back from practice, you dirty birds.) My boyfriend (both basketball player and card-carrying member of the AV club) was super into Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin, too. Which is funny because this was the mid-'90s in Wisconsin, and I couldn't tell you why they were all about the classic rock. I remember this one time at orchestra camp (even better than band camp!) one of my friends was just hanging out in the courtyard playing "Basketcase" by Green Day on the guitar. (He's a member of about eight popular bands now, including a cover band.) It was one of those perfect moments, when you see someone playing a song that's not too new and not too old and he knows it by heart and you are thisclose to singing along. I think everybody has a phase when SOMEONE around them discovers The Cure. posted by Madamina at 12:11 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Night Swimming by REM posted by WeekendJen at 12:11 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Broken Social Scene "Anthems for a Seventeen Year Old Girl" Brand New "Soco Amaretto Lime" The Dandy Warhols "We Used to Be Friends" (association with being the Veronica Mars theme song) Beck "Loser" posted by haveanicesummer at 12:14 PM on October 20, 2010 Matt Kresling's Seventeen Not from the time period, but a newer song and great video that brought a ton of memories swelling right up. posted by oldefortran at 12:20 PM on October 20, 2010 "Knights in White Satin," by the Moody Blues was played at every high school dance I ever attended. That and "Stairway to Heaven" by Zep. And there'd be a long line of boys leaning against back of the gym wall, watching and listening, but too shy to ask a girl to dance to a slow song. posted by Marie Mon Dieu at 12:25 PM on October 20, 2010 Not sure if this is quite what you're looking for, but Bruce Springsteen's "Glory Days" is pretty much the quintessential song ABOUT high school nostalgia. posted by sparrow89 at 12:55 PM on October 20, 2010 Bittersweet Symphony - The Verve. It gets bonus points because it's featured in a film about high school. posted by tryniti at 12:56 PM on October 20, 2010 Travis - "20". I can only find live versions because it was a hidden bonus track on their album. Pretty great version of it though. posted by cali59 at 1:20 PM on October 20, 2010 Maybe it says something about my high school experience, but Greetings in Braille by the Elected nails high school for me like no other song. posted by PhoBWanKenobi at 1:23 PM on October 20, 2010 Oh, also, a few years ago I was on one of those Birthright trips to Israel, and everyone from my group was sitting around a campfire in the middle of the desert, singing "Wonderwall" by Oasis, with camels watching us. I had the weird experience of walking off to use the bathroom, and passing another group playing the exact same song, even though they were out of earshot. I've decided that if there's one song that defines people my age (26ish) and that everyone from my generation knows from adolescence, it's "Wonderwall." posted by PhoBWanKenobi at 1:39 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Bittersweet autumn wouldn't be complete without Bob Seger's "Night Moves." It's someone else's youth--the recycled memories of another generation that crowded the airwaves of my own teenage years--but the longing and the nostalgia speak to me, remind me of how I felt with my high school boyfriend. It moves me still, despite watching him marry and age and parent on Facebook. "I awoke last night to the sound of thunder How far off I sat and wondered Started humming a song from 1962 Ain't it funny how the night moves When you just don't seem to have as much to lose Strange how the night moves With autumn closing in..." posted by MonkeyToes at 1:57 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] I grew up in L.A. in the 80's and would also vote for: *Anything by the Go-Go's *Anything by the Beastie Boys *Anything by the Cure *Anything by Siouxie and the Banshees/The Creatures *Don't you forget about me - Simple Minds *Obsession - Animotion *Nemesis - Shriekback posted by Sophie1 at 2:24 PM on October 20, 2010 The Smiths, of course. posted by bluedaisy at 2:57 PM on October 20, 2010 I can't believe I'm seriously recommending anything by Berry Manilow, but his The Kid Inside fits your theme. posted by zachlipton at 4:04 PM on October 20, 2010 Hayden- Everything I Long For Eric's Trip- Love Tara Portishead- Dummy posted by to recite so charmingly at 4:47 PM on October 20, 2010 The Odelay album by Beck was great to listen to in high school. As was Weezer's Blue album. And I think the Beach Boys just have an overall nostalgic feel--not necessarily high school, but a longing for the past. "I Just Wasn't Made for These Times" may be brilliantly suited for you right now. posted by shortyJBot at 4:54 PM on October 20, 2010 KMFDM - The Problem posted by Godwin Interjection at 7:48 PM on October 20, 2010 Oh my god, this thread. It's got me right back there, going to awkward parties, hanging out in coffeeshop parking lots, and thinking, yeah, I should try out for the school play! I'm not sure I can add anything new, but I'll try. Albums: No Doubt - Tragic Kingdom Poe - Hello Tori Amos - Any of her first three Green Day - Dookie They Might Be Giants - Flood Soul Coughing - Ruby Vroom or Irresistible Bliss Squirrel Nut Zippers - Hot Sunny Day Real Estate - Their first two records, I forget the names Violent Femmes - Violent Femmes Beck - Odelay Weezer - Blue Album Ben Folds Five - Their first two records Eels - Beautiful Freak or Electro-Shock Blues Smashing Pumpkins - Mellon Collie or earlier Eric's Trip - Anything by them Fountains of Wayne - their debut album, maybe Utopia Parkway as well Nirvana - Nevermind and later Alanis Morisette - Jagged Little Pill (seriously!) You've got Bush and Radiohead covered, but don't forget Stone Temple Pilots, Live, or any of those other similar groups. (Also, the suggestion upthread about ska is spot on.) I'd also try and brainstorm the music that arty high schoolers get into because they see it as a step more literary than their usual tastes, like stuff by Leonard Cohen, "The Butcher's Tale" by The Zombies, or, jesus, anything using a string quartet, really. (Also, hey, your debut is out in March? Good luck!) posted by greenland at 10:43 PM on October 20, 2010 I graduated from high school in 2000 and have strong musical associations with 1998-1999. Blink-182 - Dammit Blink-182 - All The Small Things Garbage - When I Grow Up Nerf Herder - New Jersey Girl Dashboard Confessional - Again I Go Unnoticed Lit - My Own Worst Enemy DMX - Party Up Blessid Union of Souls - Hey Leonardo(She Likes Me) Backstreet Boys - anything (I didn't say I LIKED these...) Green Day - Good Riddance Fatboy Slim - The Rockafeller Skank Beastie Boys - Intergalactic Barenaked Ladies - One Week posted by knile at 6:09 AM on October 21, 2010 Response by poster: oh my goodness, this thread is fantastic. thank you so, so much for all the fantastic recs, everyone! to be clear, the book doesn't actually take place WHEN I grew up, so much as WHERE -- teens are typically uninterested in YA novels set past decades, unless they're far back enough to be considered historical (which nowadays includes the 60s!). but music from my high school era (97-01) totally takes me back, and that's the feeling I'll be seeking as I write this, so, awesome! though I love the other eras represented in the thread, too. and seriously, some of these songs... time to stare off into the middle distance misty-eyed or something. (and thanks, greenland -- yes, March! eek!) posted by changeling at 7:47 AM on October 21, 2010 Thurston Moore's (or Cat Power's cover of) "Psychic Hearts" (starts at 0:45). posted by ifjuly at 10:12 AM on October 21, 2010 Ohoh, and Sleater-Kinney's "Surf Song" which includes Carrie reciting a letter she wrote Corin in high school. "You Ain't It" comes to mind too, for that feeling you get as a teenage girl in HS/college when all the too-cool musician guys you hang with kind of make you want to roll your eyes (Liz Phair has songs about that too). And for my money, no song encapsulates better the kind of flipped out claustophobia that happens when you're a teenager struggling with not fitting in because of unorthodox gender performance, feminism, queer identity, etc. than "Call the Doctor". "Taking Me Home" and "I'm Not Waiting" evokes a certain confused-and-upset era of girl-to-ladyhood too. And there's always "Youth Decay". posted by ifjuly at 10:22 AM on October 21, 2010 Thought of more this evening. (In part, you can totally tell I had an angsty girlysounds-type adolescence...) Team Dresch - "Growing Up in Springfield", "D.A. Don't Care" the Butchies - "Mandy" Bikini Kill - "I Hate Danger" Heavens to Betsy - "My Red Self" Sleater-Kinney (yet again!) - "Lora's Song" mostly 'cause there's something about the singing style that reminds me of being a 14 year old girl so well... posted by ifjuly at 5:04 PM on October 21, 2010 The Mountain Goats - Palmcorder Yajna & This Year Placebo - Every You Every Me The Verve - Bittersweet Symphony Third Eye Blind - Motorcycle Drive By and why the hell not... Harvey Danger - Flagpole Sitta posted by clearly at 6:36 AM on October 22, 2010 I didn't go to school in California, but if I had to pick 3 works to describe The Shins' Oh, Inverted World, I would pick California, High School and Autumn/Fall. posted by Jon Mitchell at 1:06 PM on October 29, 2010 A friend reminded me of this, uh, gem: Vertical Horizon - Everything You Want Some angst: Poe - Hey Pretty (Drive-By 2001 Mix) Tracy Bonham - Mother Mother Marcy Playground - Sex and Candy Billboard charts from the 90s will ruin my productivity this morning. posted by knile at 1:43 AM on December 3, 2010 ¬´ Older What do I need to learn in library school before I... | Suffering movie amnesia torture Newer ¬ª This thread is closed to new comments. researchResults.title: that high school feeling - playlists music writing | Ask MetaFilter New Site Beta Testing || ChatGPT policy updated || February Site Update || Non Profit FAQ Ask MetaFilter ============== querying the hive mind Log In Sign Up MetaFilter AskMeFi FanFare Projects Music Jobs IRL MetaTalk More Best Of Podcast Chat Labs Mall Search MetaFilter‚Ä¶ Menu Home FAQ About Archives Tags Popular Random that high school feeling October 20, 2010 10:48 AM Subscribe ================================================================================================================================ Songs that evoke high school nostalgia? It's that time again! I'm close to starting my fourth novel, and that means composing a playlist with metafilter's help. This book is a dark contemporary young adult book, set in the sort of central/southern California setting where I grew up. Not in summer, but in fall or winter, with overcast skies and oaks and eucalyptus trees and strawberry fields and shivering at beach bonfires and grimy coffee shops. I listen to the same long playlist every time I sit down to write a book. For this book, I'm looking for songs that convey a sense of high school nostalgia. Songs that re-evoke that excitement, fear, wistfulness, longing, confusion from your teenage years. Maybe they're songs from a pivotal time in your life. Maybe they were just hugely popular back then. Ideally, music you love; "Hit Me Baby One More Time" takes me back but it's not exactly conducive to writing. (Or listening.) I prefer rock of any kind, from indie to folk to punk to grunge -- I'm sure the subgenre depends on when you were in high school. But I'm also looking for newer songs that evoke that thrill/terror of being a teenager. The lyrics don't necessarily have to fit, but of course it's extra cool if they do. For me, some of them are "1979" by The Smashing Pumpkins (and the video!), "Glycerine" by Bush, "High and Dry" by Radiohead, etc.; songs not from my high school years, but that still evoke that feeling are "Don't Change" by INXS, "Re: Stacks" by Bon Iver, "The Last Word" by Chris Flew, "Slow Show" by The National (but that song makes me nostalgic for all times, including now). There's a definite genre theme there, but really I'd love to know your choices whatever the genre. Thanks!!! You have no idea how much this helps me write -- Metafilter's definitely going in the acknowledgments of my next book(s). posted by changeling to Media & Arts (56 answers total) 28 users marked this as a favorite The pixies doolittle got me through high school. posted by TheBones at 10:54 AM on October 20, 2010 As someone who went to hs in SoCal in the 90's, I'd have to say Ska. Lots and lots of Ska. And some surfer punk stuff. Reel big fish, No Doubt, Squirrel Nut Zippers, The Ziggens, Sublime, The Mighty Mighty Bosstones, The Aquabats, etc. posted by Arbac at 10:55 AM on October 20, 2010 Simple Minds - Don't You Forget About Me for the 80's posted by Sukey Says at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 [4 favorites] I think the Violent Femmes' eponymous first album is the sound of being sixteen, but then, I grew up in the late 80s and early 90s. Their songs' being vulgar and somewhat transgressive is what I think contributes that feel...it just fits with the sense of teenagers always wanting to be older than they are. posted by jocelmeow at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Popular by Nada Surf Freshman by The Verve Pipe posted by zoomorphic at 10:57 AM on October 20, 2010 the freshmen -- the verve pipe spiderwebs -- no doubt banditos -- the refreshments just -- radiohead & anything from the clueless soundtrack posted by crawfo at 10:58 AM on October 20, 2010 Dropout by Urge Overkill posted by kimdog at 11:00 AM on October 20, 2010 And now, with more link! Dropout by Urge Overkill posted by kimdog at 11:01 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] I went to high school in the 90s too. Some of my old favorites that evoke that high school feeling: - The Verve: The Freshmen (on preview, nthing this one) - Red Hot Chili Peppers: Under the Bridge - No Doubt: Don't Speak - Pearl Jam: Black - Candlebox: Far Behind - Violent Femmes: Kiss Off posted by spinto at 11:01 AM on October 20, 2010 The Fun Boy Three version of Our Lips Are Sealed has always had a really school/teenage sort of feeling for me. oh my god look at terry hall's hair Also Blur's Boys And Girls and Pulp's Mis-Shapes from my teenage Britpop years. And more recently, The Long Blondes' Once And Never Again. posted by permafrost at 11:02 AM on October 20, 2010 Also went to high school in Southern California. 2nding Sublime, although it reminds me of summer, not fall. Definitely Weezer, I'd say anything on The Blue Album. 3rd eye blind and Matchbox 20 always remind me of high school (but I don't think I'd want them on a playlist, ever). Neko Case "That Teenage Feeling" gives me a good nostalgic feeling. Also: The Violent Femmes, Elliot Smith, Jeff Buckley, Fiona Apple, 311, Incubus... The Romeo and Juliet Soundtrack. Bands from my older brother's ipod (who still listens to all the same music we listened to in high school): Radiohead, Nada Surf, Everclear, Hey Stroker, MxPx... I'll try to come back with more. And please post your playlist when you're done!!! On preview: Yes to Red Hot Chili Peppers posted by thankyouforyourconsideration at 11:05 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Some songs at the nostalgic and/or wistful end of the spectrum that have that effect on me (was a teenager during the mid-1990s in the UK): David's Last Summer by Pulp; The Summer House by the Divine Comedy; Wake Up Boo by the Boo Radleys; Lost Myself by the Longpigs; Mmm Mmm Mmm Mmm by the Crash Test Dummies; Today by the Smashing Pumpkins. posted by greycap at 11:06 AM on October 20, 2010 Pop A Top by Jim Ed Brown I am OLD posted by raildr at 11:07 AM on October 20, 2010 For me it would be U2's first album, Boy. Lots of songs about growing up, being a teenager, being confused about the world. Classic Edge guitar. Very 80s. Also the song Boy/Girl, off their first EP. I wore out a cassette I made with every B-Side up through the Joshua Tree. Along those lines The Alarm had a lot of songs about believing in yourself and other crap like that. 68 Guns, Knife Edge, Where Were You Hiding (When the storm broke), Strength. More great 80s guitar. posted by bondcliff at 11:09 AM on October 20, 2010 Psychedelic Furs, Love My Way posted by Cool Papa Bell at 11:19 AM on October 20, 2010 Seconding Weezer - Pinkerton and the Green Album in particular posted by aintthattheway at 11:22 AM on October 20, 2010 It came out twenty years before I graduated high school (and that was almost twenty years ago), but there might not be a song more evocative of high school in general than Big Star's "Thirteen". The first time I heard it I was just blown away by how perfect it felt, and despite its vintage it couldn't sound fresher if it were written yesterday and recorded this morning. For me personally--the Cure's "Disintegration" album. "Smells Like Teen Spirit". Metallica's black album, which reminds me of dirty dark desert parties. posted by padraigin at 11:23 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Green Day - Good Riddance (Time of Your Life) Eve 6 - Here's to the Night posted by morganannie at 11:23 AM on October 20, 2010 November Rain by Guns 'N Roses. posted by Sassyfras at 11:24 AM on October 20, 2010 Catch 22 - Kristina She Don't Know I Exist posted by namewithoutwords at 11:40 AM on October 20, 2010 New Radicals - You Get What You Give posted by Mr Mister at 11:41 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Led Zeppelin, pretty much anything by them. I remember watching The Song Remains The Same and that was the soundtrack for my high school years. KISS was big then too. This was prior to 1982. posted by JJ86 at 11:47 AM on October 20, 2010 Guster's "One Man Wrecking Machine" and "Homecoming King" are on the looking-back-on-high-school end of things, but I'd say very appropriate. A lot of Jimmy Eat World songs capture all the high school emotions for me. "The Middle" was big just before I entered high school, and "Your House," "Authority Song," and "Kill" are very good at evoking the self-conscious uncertainty of having a crush on someone and worrying about every single thing you do around them because what if you look like an idiot, and what if they don't like you back, is everyone looking at me, and all that drama. Finally, this may just be because these guys are from the same town as I am, but "Madeline" by Tickle Me Pink vividly conjures up memories from my high school days. posted by lilac girl at 11:48 AM on October 20, 2010 Pearl Jam - Jeremy and Daughter both remind me of high school posted by yawper at 11:49 AM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Songs that re-evoke that...wistfulness, longing These aren't necessarily songs that you would strongly associate with high school, but they definitely evoke wistfulness and longing for something that has passed. The Moody Blues - Your Wildest Dreams Lou Reed - Perfect Day posted by jedicus at 11:50 AM on October 20, 2010 For me that song is San Dimas High School Football Rules, by The Ataris. posted by just_ducky at 11:51 AM on October 20, 2010 American Music - Violent Femmes Story of My Life - Social Distortion Surf Wax America - Weezer Waiting Room - Fugazi 3 Days - Jane's Addiction Pepper - Butthole Surfers What's Up? - 4 Non Blondes Bad Town - Operation Ivy Punk Rock Girl - Dead Milkmen 1 Crush - Garbage Everybody Knows - Leonard Cohen Jerry Was a Racecar Driver - Primus Here Comes Your Man - Pixies Tuesday Morning - the Pogues posted by iamkimiam at 11:55 AM on October 20, 2010 [3 favorites] Concrete Blonde - Tomorrow Wendy, Joey Ben Folds Five - Brick Sinead O'Connor - Nothing Compares 2 U U2 - With or Without You And not rap, but the lyrics are all about high school: John Mayer - No Such Thing. I am a Mayer fan, but I hate this song. However, for wistful and longing, try Something's Missing. It's much better. posted by yawper at 12:00 PM on October 20, 2010 "Linger" by The Cranberries. posted by Lucinda at 12:00 PM on October 20, 2010 You want Losing My Religion by REM. I would want the first Counting Crows album, maybe some Gin Blossoms. If you were cooler than that in high school (and it sounds it), I think you want the Smiths. posted by clavicle at 12:03 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Anything by Rush or Boston immediately brings me back to an old van filled with hockey players. (On the way back from practice, you dirty birds.) My boyfriend (both basketball player and card-carrying member of the AV club) was super into Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin, too. Which is funny because this was the mid-'90s in Wisconsin, and I couldn't tell you why they were all about the classic rock. I remember this one time at orchestra camp (even better than band camp!) one of my friends was just hanging out in the courtyard playing "Basketcase" by Green Day on the guitar. (He's a member of about eight popular bands now, including a cover band.) It was one of those perfect moments, when you see someone playing a song that's not too new and not too old and he knows it by heart and you are thisclose to singing along. I think everybody has a phase when SOMEONE around them discovers The Cure. posted by Madamina at 12:11 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Night Swimming by REM posted by WeekendJen at 12:11 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Broken Social Scene "Anthems for a Seventeen Year Old Girl" Brand New "Soco Amaretto Lime" The Dandy Warhols "We Used to Be Friends" (association with being the Veronica Mars theme song) Beck "Loser" posted by haveanicesummer at 12:14 PM on October 20, 2010 Matt Kresling's Seventeen Not from the time period, but a newer song and great video that brought a ton of memories swelling right up. posted by oldefortran at 12:20 PM on October 20, 2010 "Knights in White Satin," by the Moody Blues was played at every high school dance I ever attended. That and "Stairway to Heaven" by Zep. And there'd be a long line of boys leaning against back of the gym wall, watching and listening, but too shy to ask a girl to dance to a slow song. posted by Marie Mon Dieu at 12:25 PM on October 20, 2010 Not sure if this is quite what you're looking for, but Bruce Springsteen's "Glory Days" is pretty much the quintessential song ABOUT high school nostalgia. posted by sparrow89 at 12:55 PM on October 20, 2010 Bittersweet Symphony - The Verve. It gets bonus points because it's featured in a film about high school. posted by tryniti at 12:56 PM on October 20, 2010 Travis - "20". I can only find live versions because it was a hidden bonus track on their album. Pretty great version of it though. posted by cali59 at 1:20 PM on October 20, 2010 Maybe it says something about my high school experience, but Greetings in Braille by the Elected nails high school for me like no other song. posted by PhoBWanKenobi at 1:23 PM on October 20, 2010 Oh, also, a few years ago I was on one of those Birthright trips to Israel, and everyone from my group was sitting around a campfire in the middle of the desert, singing "Wonderwall" by Oasis, with camels watching us. I had the weird experience of walking off to use the bathroom, and passing another group playing the exact same song, even though they were out of earshot. I've decided that if there's one song that defines people my age (26ish) and that everyone from my generation knows from adolescence, it's "Wonderwall." posted by PhoBWanKenobi at 1:39 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] Bittersweet autumn wouldn't be complete without Bob Seger's "Night Moves." It's someone else's youth--the recycled memories of another generation that crowded the airwaves of my own teenage years--but the longing and the nostalgia speak to me, remind me of how I felt with my high school boyfriend. It moves me still, despite watching him marry and age and parent on Facebook. "I awoke last night to the sound of thunder How far off I sat and wondered Started humming a song from 1962 Ain't it funny how the night moves When you just don't seem to have as much to lose Strange how the night moves With autumn closing in..." posted by MonkeyToes at 1:57 PM on October 20, 2010 [1 favorite] I grew up in L.A. in the 80's and would also vote for: *Anything by the Go-Go's *Anything by the Beastie Boys *Anything by the Cure *Anything by Siouxie and the Banshees/The Creatures *Don't you forget about me - Simple Minds *Obsession - Animotion *Nemesis - Shriekback posted by Sophie1 at 2:24 PM on October 20, 2010 The Smiths, of course. posted by bluedaisy at 2:57 PM on October 20, 2010 I can't believe I'm seriously recommending anything by Berry Manilow, but his The Kid Inside fits your theme. posted by zachlipton at 4:04 PM on October 20, 2010 Hayden- Everything I Long For Eric's Trip- Love Tara Portishead- Dummy posted by to recite so charmingly at 4:47 PM on October 20, 2010 The Odelay album by Beck was great to listen to in high school. As was Weezer's Blue album. And I think the Beach Boys just have an overall nostalgic feel--not necessarily high school, but a longing for the past. "I Just Wasn't Made for These Times" may be brilliantly suited for you right now. posted by shortyJBot at 4:54 PM on October 20, 2010 KMFDM - The Problem posted by Godwin Interjection at 7:48 PM on October 20, 2010 Oh my god, this thread. It's got me right back there, going to awkward parties, hanging out in coffeeshop parking lots, and thinking, yeah, I should try out for the school play! I'm not sure I can add anything new, but I'll try. Albums: No Doubt - Tragic Kingdom Poe - Hello Tori Amos - Any of her first three Green Day - Dookie They Might Be Giants - Flood Soul Coughing - Ruby Vroom or Irresistible Bliss Squirrel Nut Zippers - Hot Sunny Day Real Estate - Their first two records, I forget the names Violent Femmes - Violent Femmes Beck - Odelay Weezer - Blue Album Ben Folds Five - Their first two records Eels - Beautiful Freak or Electro-Shock Blues Smashing Pumpkins - Mellon Collie or earlier Eric's Trip - Anything by them Fountains of Wayne - their debut album, maybe Utopia Parkway as well Nirvana - Nevermind and later Alanis Morisette - Jagged Little Pill (seriously!) You've got Bush and Radiohead covered, but don't forget Stone Temple Pilots, Live, or any of those other similar groups. (Also, the suggestion upthread about ska is spot on.) I'd also try and brainstorm the music that arty high schoolers get into because they see it as a step more literary than their usual tastes, like stuff by Leonard Cohen, "The Butcher's Tale" by The Zombies, or, jesus, anything using a string quartet, really. (Also, hey, your debut is out in March? Good luck!) posted by greenland at 10:43 PM on October 20, 2010 I graduated from high school in 2000 and have strong musical associations with 1998-1999. Blink-182 - Dammit Blink-182 - All The Small Things Garbage - When I Grow Up Nerf Herder - New Jersey Girl Dashboard Confessional - Again I Go Unnoticed Lit - My Own Worst Enemy DMX - Party Up Blessid Union of Souls - Hey Leonardo(She Likes Me) Backstreet Boys - anything (I didn't say I LIKED these...) Green Day - Good Riddance Fatboy Slim - The Rockafeller Skank Beastie Boys - Intergalactic Barenaked Ladies - One Week posted by knile at 6:09 AM on October 21, 2010 Response by poster: oh my goodness, this thread is fantastic. thank you so, so much for all the fantastic recs, everyone! to be clear, the book doesn't actually take place WHEN I grew up, so much as WHERE -- teens are typically uninterested in YA novels set past decades, unless they're far back enough to be considered historical (which nowadays includes the 60s!). but music from my high school era (97-01) totally takes me back, and that's the feeling I'll be seeking as I write this, so, awesome! though I love the other eras represented in the thread, too. and seriously, some of these songs... time to stare off into the middle distance misty-eyed or something. (and thanks, greenland -- yes, March! eek!) posted by changeling at 7:47 AM on October 21, 2010 Thurston Moore's (or Cat Power's cover of) "Psychic Hearts" (starts at 0:45). posted by ifjuly at 10:12 AM on October 21, 2010 Ohoh, and Sleater-Kinney's "Surf Song" which includes Carrie reciting a letter she wrote Corin in high school. "You Ain't It" comes to mind too, for that feeling you get as a teenage girl in HS/college when all the too-cool musician guys you hang with kind of make you want to roll your eyes (Liz Phair has songs about that too). And for my money, no song encapsulates better the kind of flipped out claustophobia that happens when you're a teenager struggling with not fitting in because of unorthodox gender performance, feminism, queer identity, etc. than "Call the Doctor". "Taking Me Home" and "I'm Not Waiting" evokes a certain confused-and-upset era of girl-to-ladyhood too. And there's always "Youth Decay". posted by ifjuly at 10:22 AM on October 21, 2010 Thought of more this evening. (In part, you can totally tell I had an angsty girlysounds-type adolescence...) Team Dresch - "Growing Up in Springfield", "D.A. Don't Care" the Butchies - "Mandy" Bikini Kill - "I Hate Danger" Heavens to Betsy - "My Red Self" Sleater-Kinney (yet again!) - "Lora's Song" mostly 'cause there's something about the singing style that reminds me of being a 14 year old girl so well... posted by ifjuly at 5:04 PM on October 21, 2010 The Mountain Goats - Palmcorder Yajna & This Year Placebo - Every You Every Me The Verve - Bittersweet Symphony Third Eye Blind - Motorcycle Drive By and why the hell not... Harvey Danger - Flagpole Sitta posted by clearly at 6:36 AM on October 22, 2010 I didn't go to school in California, but if I had to pick 3 works to describe The Shins' Oh, Inverted World, I would pick California, High School and Autumn/Fall. posted by Jon Mitchell at 1:06 PM on October 29, 2010 A friend reminded me of this, uh, gem: Vertical Horizon - Everything You Want Some angst: Poe - Hey Pretty (Drive-By 2001 Mix) Tracy Bonham - Mother Mother Marcy Playground - Sex and Candy Billboard charts from the 90s will ruin my productivity this morning. posted by knile at 1:43 AM on December 3, 2010 ¬´ Older What do I need to learn in library school before I... | Suffering movie amnesia torture Newer ¬ª This thread is closed to new comments. researchResults.content: Published Time: 2024-11-01T04:52:52+00:00 29 Greatest & Best Songs About Nostalgia (Ultimate Playlist) - Public Domain Music Skip to content Blog Learn Music Theory Music Lessons Guitar Lessons Guitar Tricks Jamplay Fender Play TrueFire ArtistWorks Music History Music Styles Composers American Composers Music Eras Musicians Song Meanings Playlists Instruments About 29 Greatest & Best Songs About Nostalgia (Ultimate Playlist) Home > Playlists > 29 Greatest & Best Songs About Nostalgia (Ultimate Playlist) Nostalgia in music is a powerful force that transports us to the past, invoking memories of times gone by. Songs about nostalgia capture the essence of reflection, allowing us to relive moments of joy, sadness, love, and growth. Whether it‚Äôs the lyrics that echo a long-lost memory or a melody that brings back the sound of a different era, these songs have a unique way of connecting listeners to their personal histories. In this collection of songs about nostalgia, we explore tracks that resonate with memories of youth, relationships, and milestones. Each song offers a window into the past, reminding us of the moments that have shaped who we are today. 29 Most Popular Songs About Nostalgia That Will Bring You Back (Must Hear Playlist) Contents 1 29 Most Popular Songs About Nostalgia That Will Bring You Back (Must Hear Playlist) 2 #1 ‚ÄúSummer of ‚Äô69‚Äù by Bryan Adams 3 #2 ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù by The Beatles 4 #3 ‚ÄúGlory Days‚Äù by Bruce Springsteen 5 #4 ‚Äú1979‚Äù by Smashing Pumpkins 6 #5 ‚ÄúIn My Life‚Äù by The Beatles 7 #6 ‚ÄúJack and Diane‚Äù by John Mellencamp 8 #7 ‚ÄúThe Boys of Summer‚Äù by Don Henley 9 #8 ‚ÄúWe Are Young‚Äù by fun. feat. Janelle Mon√°e 10 #9 ‚ÄúTake Me Home, Country Roads‚Äù by John Denver 11 #10 ‚ÄúPhotograph‚Äù by Nickelback 12 #11 ‚ÄúFast Car‚Äù by Tracy Chapman 13 #12 ‚ÄúLandslide‚Äù by Fleetwood Mac 14 #13 ‚ÄúThe Night They Drove Old Dixie Down‚Äù by The Band 15 #14 ‚ÄúI Will Remember You‚Äù by Sarah McLachlan 16 #15 ‚ÄúCastle on the Hill‚Äù by Ed Sheeran 17 #16 ‚ÄúWake Me Up When September Ends‚Äù by Green Day 18 #17 ‚ÄúStill Fighting It‚Äù by Ben Folds 19 #18 ‚ÄúAuld Lang Syne‚Äù by Robert Burns (traditional) 20 #19 ‚ÄúAll Summer Long‚Äù by Kid Rock 21 #20 ‚ÄúThose Were the Days‚Äù by Mary Hopkin 22 #21 ‚ÄúPiano Man‚Äù by Billy Joel 23 #22 ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù by Maroon 5 24 #23 ‚ÄúOld Friends‚Äù by Simon & Garfunkel 25 #24 ‚ÄúChanges‚Äù by David Bowie 26 #25 ‚ÄúGood Riddance (Time of Your Life)‚Äù by Green Day 27 #26 ‚ÄúRemember When‚Äù by Alan Jackson 28 #27 ‚ÄúSummer Nights‚Äù by Olivia Newton-John & John Travolta 29 #28 ‚ÄúThe Way We Were‚Äù by Barbra Streisand 30 #29 ‚ÄúWhen We Were Young‚Äù by Adele 31 Frequently Asked Questions 31.1 What makes a song nostalgic? 31.2 Why do nostalgic songs resonate so deeply with listeners? 31.3 Are nostalgic songs always sad or melancholic? 31.4 Can a song become nostalgic over time? These songs are about nostalgic memories and reminiscing about the good old days when you were young. Here is a list of 29 songs about nostalgia: 1 ‚ÄúSummer of ‚Äô69‚Äù by Bryan Adams Bryan Adams‚Äô ‚ÄúSummer of ‚Äô69‚Äù is a quintessential song about youthful nostalgia, capturing the carefree days of adolescence. Through the lens of the summer of ‚Äô69, Adams reminisces about love, friendship, and playing in a rock band, all wrapped in the innocence and recklessness of youth. The imagery of buying his first real six-string and playing until his fingers bled evokes a time when everything felt limitless, and dreams seemed within reach. The song speaks to the universal longing to relive the simpler, happier moments of youth. It‚Äôs not just about the specific year but the universal feeling of looking back with fondness on a time when life felt pure and unburdened. 2 ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù by The Beatles ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù by The Beatles is a melancholic anthem for lost time and regret, making it one of the most iconic nostalgia songs ever written. Paul McCartney‚Äôs yearning lyrics reflect on a time when things were simpler, before life‚Äôs complications and heartaches took over. The softness of the melody, paired with the emotional weight of McCartney‚Äôs vocals, creates a powerful reflection on how everything can change in the blink of an eye. The song conveys a longing for a return to a time when troubles were distant, and life seemed whole. It‚Äôs a poignant reminder of how fleeting moments of happiness can be, making us treasure our yesterdays all the more. 3 ‚ÄúGlory Days‚Äù by Bruce Springsteen Bruce Springsteen‚Äôs ‚ÄúGlory Days‚Äù dives headfirst into the bittersweet experience of recalling the past. Through the stories of a baseball player and a woman who once had it all, Springsteen paints a picture of people who are well past their prime but can‚Äôt let go of their ‚Äòglory days.‚Äô His raw vocals and the upbeat melody contrast with the underlying sadness of the song, capturing the blend of joy and sorrow that comes with remembering what once was. The song reminds us that while it‚Äôs wonderful to remember the high points of life, those moments are behind us. Its message is clear: nostalgia can be both a comforting friend and a harsh reminder of time‚Äôs relentless march forward. 4 ‚Äú1979‚Äù by Smashing Pumpkins Smashing Pumpkins‚Äô ‚Äú1979‚Äù captures the essence of suburban teenage life and the hazy, carefree days of youth. With lyrics that weave together memories of cruising around aimlessly and the aimlessness of adolescence, the song reflects a time before adulthood‚Äôs responsibilities set in. The shimmering guitar work and Billy Corgan‚Äôs ethereal vocals help convey a dreamy sense of nostalgia, where memories blur into one endless summer. The song perfectly encapsulates the feeling of looking back on teenage years, not with a sense of regret but with a sense of wonder at how innocent and spontaneous life felt at that age. It‚Äôs a tribute to a fleeting time when the world seemed wide open. 5 ‚ÄúIn My Life‚Äù by The Beatles ‚ÄúIn My Life‚Äù by The Beatles is a tender reflection on the people, places, and moments that have shaped a person‚Äôs existence. John Lennon‚Äôs heartfelt lyrics, paired with the gentle melody, create a reflective tone that touches on both the joy and sadness of looking back. The song is about cherishing memories of the past while also recognizing that the present and future hold equal importance. With its timeless melody and universal theme, ‚ÄúIn My Life‚Äù resonates with listeners across generations, reminding us that while we hold onto our past, we continue to evolve, and life goes on, shaped by our memories and experiences. 6 ‚ÄúJack and Diane‚Äù by John Mellencamp John Mellencamp‚Äôs ‚ÄúJack and Diane‚Äù is a nostalgic look at small-town America and the fleeting nature of youth. Through the story of a young couple, Mellencamp captures the innocence and simplicity of teenage love, set against the backdrop of a life full of potential. The catchy chorus, ‚ÄúOh yeah, life goes on, long after the thrill of living is gone,‚Äù sums up the song‚Äôs message about how quickly those youthful moments pass by. The song evokes a sense of longing for the carefree days of youth, reminding listeners that no matter how much we try to hold onto those memories, time inevitably moves on, and we have to grow up. 7 ‚ÄúThe Boys of Summer‚Äù by Don Henley Don Henley‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Boys of Summer‚Äù is a nostalgic anthem that captures the feeling of longing for lost youth and love. The song reflects on the fleeting nature of summer and how time moves forward, leaving behind those golden moments that once felt eternal. Henley‚Äôs reflective lyrics, paired with the haunting melody, create a sense of yearning for the past while acknowledging that it‚Äôs gone. The line ‚ÄúI can see you, your brown skin shining in the sun‚Äù evokes vivid memories of a love tied to a specific time and place. The song is a reminder that while we can‚Äôt go back, those memories will always linger just beneath the surface, haunting yet cherished. 8 ‚ÄúWe Are Young‚Äù by fun. feat. Frequently Asked Questions What makes a song nostalgic? A song is considered nostalgic when it evokes memories of the past, often stirring emotions tied to specific moments or experiences. Nostalgic songs typically feature reflective lyrics and melodies that remind listeners of simpler times or significant life events. Why do nostalgic songs resonate so deeply with listeners? Nostalgic songs resonate because they tap into personal memories, creating an emotional connection with the listener. Music has a unique ability to trigger vivid recollections, allowing people to relive moments from their past. Are nostalgic songs always sad or melancholic? Not all nostalgic songs are sad; many simply reflect on happy memories or bittersweet moments. Nostalgia can evoke a wide range of emotions, from joy and warmth to a gentle sadness over times gone by. Can a song become nostalgic over time? Yes, a song can become nostalgic as it gains personal significance over time, often linked to specific life experiences. As people grow older, songs that accompanied key moments in their lives take on nostalgic meaning. The soldier‚Äôs nostalgia for the past, where his world made sense, mirrors the universal human experience of longing for a time before everything changed. The song‚Äôs soulful melody and heartfelt delivery make it a powerful reflection on how history shapes personal lives and creates nostalgia for a time that can never be reclaimed. 14 ‚ÄúI Will Remember You‚Äù by Sarah McLachlan Sarah McLachlan‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Will Remember You‚Äù is a tender ballad that perfectly captures the emotion of saying goodbye while holding onto cherished memories. With lyrics that express a deep sense of reflection and nostalgia, the song reminds listeners to appreciate every moment and person in their life before they are gone. McLachlan‚Äôs haunting voice and the song‚Äôs delicate melody make it a powerful anthem for anyone reflecting on love, loss, and the passage of time. The song serves as a gentle reminder that, while we move forward in life, the memories of those we‚Äôve known and loved will always stay with us. It‚Äôs both a celebration of life and an acknowledgment of its inevitable changes. 15 ‚ÄúCastle on the Hill‚Äù by Ed Sheeran Ed Sheeran‚Äôs ‚ÄúCastle on the Hill‚Äù is a nostalgic tribute to his hometown and the memories of his youth. With vivid imagery of carefree days spent with friends, the song transports listeners to a time when life was simpler and filled with possibility. The chorus, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on my way, driving at 90 down those country lanes,‚Äù embodies a yearning for the innocence of the past and the comfort of home. The song masterfully blends personal reflections with universal feelings of nostalgia, as Sheeran contemplates how growing up changes relationships and the way we view the world. It‚Äôs an anthem for anyone who longs to revisit the places and moments that shaped who they are. 16 ‚ÄúWake Me Up When September Ends‚Äù by Green Day ‚ÄúWake Me Up When September Ends‚Äù by Green Day is a deeply personal song written by Billie Joe Armstrong about the death of his father. While the lyrics specifically deal with loss, the song has resonated with many as an anthem for reflecting on past hardships and the desire to escape painful memories. The haunting melody and emotional depth of the song make it a powerful tribute to both grief and the passage of time. As September marks a seasonal transition, the song‚Äôs title also symbolizes a wish for the difficult times to pass, a theme that speaks to the universal experience of enduring loss and eventually finding peace. It‚Äôs a nostalgic reflection on pain and healing. 17 ‚ÄúStill Fighting It‚Äù by Ben Folds Ben Folds‚Äô ‚ÄúStill Fighting It‚Äù is a heartfelt ode to his son, capturing the bittersweet nature of watching someone grow up. The song is filled with tender reflections on the challenges and beauty of life, making it both a celebration of childhood and an acknowledgment of the struggles that come with it. Folds sings about the inevitable passage of time, noting how ‚ÄúEverybody knows it sucks to grow up.‚Äù With its gentle piano melody and emotional lyrics, ‚ÄúStill Fighting It‚Äù captures the essence of nostalgia as it reflects on the fleeting nature of youth and the universal experience of change. It‚Äôs a song that resonates with both parents and those remembering their own childhoods. 18 ‚ÄúAuld Lang Syne‚Äù by Robert Burns (traditional) ‚ÄúAuld Lang Syne,‚Äù written by Scottish poet Robert Burns, is a classic song of nostalgia often sung at New Year‚Äôs Eve celebrations. The lyrics reflect on old friendships and the passage of time, asking whether these memories should be forgotten or cherished. The song‚Äôs title translates to ‚Äúold long since‚Äù or ‚Äúdays gone by,‚Äù perfectly encapsulating the spirit of looking back with fondness on the past. Its melancholic yet hopeful melody reminds us to value the relationships and moments that have shaped us, even as we move forward into a new year. ‚ÄúAuld Lang Syne‚Äù has become a timeless anthem for reflection and sentimentality. 19 ‚ÄúAll Summer Long‚Äù by Kid Rock ‚ÄúAll Summer Long‚Äù by Kid Rock is a nostalgic tribute to carefree summer days and youthful freedom. With its catchy melody and blend of Lynyrd Skynyrd‚Äôs ‚ÄúSweet Home Alabama‚Äù and Warren Zevon‚Äôs ‚ÄúWerewolves of London,‚Äù the song instantly evokes a sense of fun and simplicity. Kid Rock‚Äôs lyrics take listeners back to the unforgettable moments of love, friendship, and good times spent by the water. The song‚Äôs infectious energy and vivid imagery of bonfires and boat rides create an atmosphere of nostalgia for a time when life was all about enjoying the moment. It‚Äôs a celebration of the best parts of summer, wrapped in memories of youthful abandon. 20 ‚ÄúThose Were the Days‚Äù by Mary Hopkin ‚ÄúThose Were the Days‚Äù by Mary Hopkin is a poignant reflection on youth and the passage of time, capturing the longing for the past. The song‚Äôs folk-inspired melody, paired with lyrics that reminisce about carefree times in ‚Äúthe tavern down the street,‚Äù evokes a deep sense of nostalgia for days gone by. Its melancholic tone underscores the bittersweet nature of looking back, knowing that those moments can never be recaptured. The song speaks to the universal experience of growing older and realizing how much life has changed, yet cherishing the memories of what once was. ‚ÄúThose Were the Days‚Äù is a timeless anthem for anyone who has ever looked back fondly on their past. 21 ‚ÄúPiano Man‚Äù by Billy Joel Billy Joel‚Äôs ‚ÄúPiano Man‚Äù is a masterful storytelling song that brings to life a cast of characters who frequent a bar, all with their own stories of nostalgia and dreams deferred. The song‚Äôs lyrics vividly paint a picture of a man playing the piano, while the patrons reflect on their lives and the dreams they‚Äôve lost along the way. Joel‚Äôs haunting harmonica and piano melody create an atmosphere of reflection and melancholy. ‚ÄúSing us a song, you‚Äôre the piano man‚Äù has become an iconic line, symbolizing the way music can bring people together in moments of shared nostalgia. It‚Äôs a timeless tribute to the power of music to evoke emotions and memories. 22 ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù by Maroon 5 ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù by Maroon 5 is a heartfelt tribute to the moments we‚Äôve lost and the people we remember. With lyrics like ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs to the ones that we got,‚Äù the song taps into universal feelings of nostalgia, grief, and gratitude. The simple, yet moving arrangement makes it a song that resonates with listeners who are reflecting on past relationships and experiences. The song‚Äôs emotion lies in its ability to stir memories of people no longer in our lives, encouraging us to raise a glass to both the good times and the bittersweet moments. It‚Äôs a modern anthem of remembrance that captures the essence of loss and love. 23 ‚ÄúOld Friends‚Äù by Simon & Garfunkel Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs ‚ÄúOld Friends‚Äù is a tender reflection on the passage of time and the enduring power of long-term friendships. With its melancholic melody and wistful lyrics, the song imagines two old friends sitting on a park bench, reminiscing about their shared pasts. The simplicity of the acoustic arrangement mirrors the quietness of those reflective moments. The beauty of ‚ÄúOld Friends‚Äù lies in its exploration of aging, nostalgia, and the comfort of companionship, making it a timeless piece about the connections that stay with us as the years go by. It‚Äôs a poignant reminder of how relationships evolve but the memories remain. 24 ‚ÄúChanges‚Äù by David Bowie David Bowie‚Äôs ‚ÄúChanges‚Äù is a dynamic exploration of personal growth, self-reflection, and the inevitable march of time. The song‚Äôs iconic refrain, ‚ÄúCh-ch-ch-ch-changes,‚Äù speaks to the bittersweet process of adapting to life‚Äôs transformations, making it a powerful anthem of nostalgia and reinvention. With its mix of piano and rock influences, ‚ÄúChanges‚Äù is both introspective and forward-looking. The song addresses both the fear and excitement of change, recognizing that while the past shapes us, the future demands that we keep evolving. Bowie‚Äôs timeless lyrics resonate with anyone reflecting on how life‚Äôs unexpected shifts have altered their path. 25 ‚ÄúGood Riddance (Time of Your Life)‚Äù by Green Day ‚ÄúGood Riddance (Time of Your Life)‚Äù by Green Day is a reflective ballad that perfectly encapsulates the mix of emotions that come with looking back on important moments in life. The acoustic-driven melody, paired with lyrics like ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something unpredictable, but in the end, it‚Äôs right,‚Äù speaks to the nostalgia of milestones like graduation or the end of a chapter. Despite its title, the song isn‚Äôt bitter; instead, it embraces the idea that life‚Äôs unpredictability can still lead to meaningful memories. It‚Äôs become a go-to anthem for reflection, reminding listeners to cherish both the ups and downs that make life memorable. 26 ‚ÄúRemember When‚Äù by Alan Jackson ‚ÄúRemember When‚Äù by Alan Jackson is a touching ballad that reminisces on a lifetime of love, growth, and change within a relationship. Through heartfelt lyrics and a gentle melody, Jackson reflects on key moments like falling in love, raising children, and growing older, all while looking back fondly on the passage of time. The song‚Äôs nostalgic tone and personal reflection make it a favorite for those looking back on their own journeys through life and love. It‚Äôs a sentimental tribute to lasting love and the memories that make it all worthwhile. 27 ‚ÄúSummer Nights‚Äù by Olivia Newton-John & John Travolta ‚ÄúSummer Nights‚Äù from the musical Grease, performed by Olivia Newton-John and John Travolta, is a fun and energetic look back at a fleeting summer romance. The upbeat tune and playful call-and-response lyrics between the characters Danny and Sandy capture the excitement, thrill, and nostalgia of summer love. Although the song is lighthearted, it still taps into the wistful feeling of reflecting on a season that has passed and the memories that remain. ‚ÄúSummer Nights‚Äù perfectly captures the carefree spirit of youth, making it a nostalgic favorite for listeners of all ages. 28 ‚ÄúThe Way We Were‚Äù by Barbra Streisand Barbra Streisand‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Way We Were‚Äù is an iconic ballad about love and loss, filled with bittersweet memories of a past relationship. With its sweeping melody and Streisand‚Äôs emotive voice, the song reflects on the beauty of what once was, asking ‚ÄúCan it be that it was all so simple then?‚Äù The song is a meditation on the nature of memories‚Äîhow they‚Äôre often seen through a nostalgic lens, making the past seem more perfect. The song‚Äôs emotional depth and universal themes of love, memory, and regret make it a timeless reflection on how we hold on to the people and moments that shaped us. 29 ‚ÄúWhen We Were Young‚Äù by Adele Adele‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhen We Were Young‚Äù is a deeply emotional song that reflects on the passage of time and the longing to relive a special moment. Her powerful vocals and haunting melody express the bittersweet feelings of looking back at youth and wishing to capture the essence of who we were at that time. The lyrics paint a vivid picture of meeting someone from the past and realizing how much has changed, evoking a profound sense of nostalgia for the days when life felt simpler. ‚ÄúWhen We Were Young‚Äù is a poignant reminder of how memories can stir up deep emotions and a yearning for the past. Frequently Asked Questions What makes a song nostalgic? A song is considered nostalgic when it evokes memories of the past, often stirring emotions tied to specific moments or experiences. Nostalgic songs typically feature reflective lyrics and melodies that remind listeners of simpler times or significant life events. Why do nostalgic songs resonate so deeply with listeners? Nostalgic songs resonate because they tap into personal memories, creating an emotional connection with the listener. Music has a unique ability to trigger vivid recollections, allowing people to relive moments from their past. Are nostalgic songs always sad or melancholic? Not all nostalgic songs are sad; many simply reflect on happy memories or bittersweet moments. Nostalgia can evoke a wide range of emotions, from joy and warmth to a gentle sadness over times gone by. Can a song become nostalgic over time? Yes, a song can become nostalgic as it gains personal significance over time, often linked to specific life experiences. As people grow older, songs that accompanied key moments in their lives take on nostalgic meaning.
